description:
GB virus C (GBV-C), also known as hepatitis G virus (HGV), is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus that belongs to the Flaviviridae family. It is closely related to the hepatitis C virus (HCV) but is considered a distinct virus.

GBV-C was first discovered in 1995 in the serum of a patient with non-A, non-B, non-C hepatitis. It is primarily transmitted through blood-borne routes, such as intravenous drug use, blood transfusions, and needle-stick injuries. However, it can also be transmitted through sexual contact and vertical transmission from mother to child.

Unlike HCV, GBV-C does not appear to cause significant liver disease in most individuals. In fact, studies have suggested that GBV-C infection may have a beneficial effect on the course of HIV infection, as it has been associated with slower disease progression and improved survival in HIV-positive individuals.

The genome of GBV-C is approximately 9.4 kilobases in length and encodes a polyprotein that is cleaved into various structural and non-structural proteins. The virus can be classified into different genotypes based on sequence variations in the viral genome.

While the clinical significance of GBV-C infection is still being investigated, it remains an interesting subject of study in the field of virology and infectious diseases.
